patterns.title: Strong Diagonal
patterns.description: A bright, continuous line running from top-left to bottom-right. This is the normal intra-chromosomal Hi-C signal — contigs within the same chromosome show strong contact frequency along the diagonal.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Bright continuous diagonal line with gradual fade-off perpendicular to the diagonal.

patterns.title: Chromosome Block
patterns.description: Square blocks along the diagonal, each representing one chromosome. Within a block, contigs have high mutual contact frequency. Between blocks, contact is much lower — this is how Hi-C reveals chromosome boundaries.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Distinct square regions of bright signal along the diagonal, separated by darker gaps.

patterns.title: Inversion (Butterfly)
patterns.description: An anti-diagonal 'butterfly' or 'bowtie' pattern at a misassembly breakpoint. This occurs when a contig segment is inverted relative to its true orientation, creating a characteristic X-shaped signal at the junction.
patterns.whatToLookFor: X-shaped or butterfly pattern where the diagonal signal briefly reverses direction.

patterns.title: Translocation
patterns.description: An off-diagonal bright block indicates contigs from different chromosomes that have been incorrectly joined in the assembly. In a correct assembly, off-diagonal signal should be minimal.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Bright rectangular block away from the main diagonal, connecting two different chromosome regions.

patterns.title: Microchromosomes
patterns.description: Many small blocks along the diagonal, common in birds and some reptiles. Bird karyotypes have numerous small microchromosomes (often 10-40), which appear as tiny bright squares near the bottom-right of the map.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Cluster of many small bright squares near the end of the diagonal.

patterns.title: Low Coverage
patterns.description: Faint or grey regions indicate low Hi-C read depth. This can happen with repetitive sequences, heterochromatin, or assembly gaps. These regions are harder to curate because the signal-to-noise ratio is poor.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Pale or nearly invisible regions along the diagonal where the contact signal is weak.

patterns.title: Unplaced Contigs
patterns.description: Small, scattered fragments typically found at the bottom-right of an uncurated map. These contigs couldn't be placed into chromosomes by the assembler and often need manual assignment during curation.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Cluster of tiny, isolated dots or very small blocks at the bottom-right corner.

patterns.title: A/B Compartments
patterns.description: A plaid or checkerboard pattern within chromosomes caused by the spatial organization of active (A) and inactive (B) chromatin compartments. This is a normal biological signal, not a misassembly.
patterns.whatToLookFor: Checkerboard-like alternating bright and dark patches within a chromosome block.
